With NFP throw out the stochs & even the 4 hour channel out the window.  
  
This is where the big boys steal everyones money   
in the USA people have beer parties in hotels & "bet" on this.  
it is wild.  
  
But in the end of the day it changes nothing  
90% everything is back to the same Monday or before.  
  
I think the cable & the Euro will keep moving up to 1.37 & even 1.4   
& this is just a buying chance.  
  
The reason I took 2.0125 is it was the bottom of the 4 hour channel   
I think it will brake it... but at the very least it will test it   
  
  
But I could be wronge!!

> Hi TEB,

>  I have opened a demo account with Oanda and think it is too good to be true. I am using my brokers real account and Oanda is 10 times better.   
>  Now the question is does Oanda take the spread at the moment of me making a trade? Because I cannot see them taking any spread, as if I had no costs with openning a position? Please clarify![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1).

Oanda doesnt charge a commission, so you can't actually see any charges on the statements. But, if you look on the price column on the left side of the platform you will see the sell price and the buy price, the deference is your spread.  
  
Example: If you were to open and close an order without the price moving, you would buy at 1.3600 and sell at 1.35988. It would have cost you 1.2 pips(the spread) for the transaction.  
  
Cheers  
  
oo7_ts

Hey mike o.,   
currently I am testing out a hybrid TEB2 using the daily and 1hr and I am entering on the daily & 1hr 5,3,3 crosses. I will also look for the 14,3,3 for confirmation because when they both line up that can be nice!  
  
I have found that when the 5,3,3 and the 14,3,3 line up you potentially can get some big moves so I use the 14,3,3 as sort of an extra confirmation at times and also I am testing it as an indicator for staying in a trade or not. For example, if I take a trade, I will watch the 14,3,3 blue line (slow stoch) to see if that heads into an overbought or oversold area. when it starts to leave that area, I might get out of a trade. this is something I believe TEB said you can try and I think spudfyre mentions it. however, I am just testing that exit technique.  
  
My results right now are win some lose some. I am trying to get to know the system better and to only take the best setups. My problem is sometimes I do not know when the trade is going against me and thus I stay in too long and get burnt. The system has provided some excellent trades though so I am trying to just stick with it because I can see that it has very good potential. To me I think forex is all about choosing a system that you can relate too and try and learn everything about that system. its strengths and weaknesses. The better I get at knowing a system and cutting my losses, the better my results will be. I really like this system. it is so simple to use and makes so much sense to me. let me know how it is going with you mike o. take care!

Then it took a brief turn up over 20 and shot right back down into "oversold" for **an entire month** again, until 6/9 or so, to the tune of **anoter 500 pips.** That's why stochs (on a single TF especially) are pretty useless during a trending market. Better for ranging, when the oscillator can do what it does best--oscillate. :-D

Teb, great job with your trendlines.  
  
It looks to me that the problem you mention here is because you may be looking for a trendline that does not yet exist. You have some very well defined ones there, but it seems that you made your second 4-hr line where price was at the moment, instead of waiting for a move away from that area first. In other words, I can make a trendline from any old swing high/low to where price is now, but it doesn't mean that price has actually tested that area yet and moved away from it, creating a boundary. And while two points may make an acceptable trendline, really 3 or more makes it a much more reliable boundary.

Hey nondisclosure...TEB's statement already contains the answer you are looking for.  
  
If you are using TEB1. Then you would use 5,3,3 stoch settings on the daily, the 1hr and then the 30m chart and wait for all of them to line up (cross).  
  
if you are using TEB2. you would place a 5,3,3 and a 14,3,3 on a 4hr and 30m chart. you would wait for the 4hr stochs to cross then enter on a 30m cross of the stochs.  
  
You can tweak certain timeframes while using this system however dont make them too close. for example looking for a 30m and then a 15m cross. Currently I am using a daily cross then looking for 1hr crosses for entry.  
  
hope this helps.

Hey guess121, the stochs, like most if not all indicators, lag behind price action. When price moves, so do the stochs. A stoch cross might be occuring at one point but if price shoots up/down in the opposite direction to the cross, then potentially the stoch can become uncrossed (depending on how high price moves and when it closes).  
  
hope this helps.

Hey guess121, backtesting can be successful because you wait for the cross to be solidified ie. wait for the candle to close. When a candle is being formed, the stochs can cross and then uncross depending on how the market is moving. therefore, I will wait for a cross to be confirmed BEFORE placing a trade. In backtesting it should prove to be the same as forward testing as you are waiting for the crosses before making a trade.

The TEB EA is based solely on TEB2. It opens positions based on those orders.   
  
**_There is no exit strategy in this EA!_** But if someone's got some good ideas, I'll entertain them. right now, it just moves the SL in accordance to the TS values, waits until the SL get hits, then closes order.  
  
Here's the meaning of some of the variables:  
_MoneyManagement_ \- Change to false to shutdown money management controls.  
_TradeSizePercent_ \- Change to whatever percent of equity you wish to risk.  
_Lots_ \- Used only if MoneyManagement if set to false.  
_LotSize_ \- Contract size of a single lot   
_Leverage_ \- leverage you get from your brokder  
_StopLoss_ \- Stop Loss  
_UseTrailingStop_ \- Use Trailing Stop  
_TrailingStopType_ \- Type 1 moves stop immediately, Type 2 waits til value of TS is reached  
_TrailingStop_ \- Pip value of trailing stop  
_UseTakeProfit_ \- Use Take Profit  
_TakeProfit_ \- Pip value of where you want take profit taken  
_Slippage_ \- For definition of slippage, google it.  
_time1_ \- Lower time frame. ie. using 4h and 30 min, this would be 30  
_time2_ \- Higher time frame. ie. using 4h and 30 min, this would be 240  
  
Take a look. Test run, etc. If we can fine tune it, I would like that. I'll post all versions as I get input back. And when we come up w/ something that's final, it'll be here for all to use.  
  
I don't want to mess w/ the MoneyManagement stuff. I know that works on other EA's I've messed with.   
  
What I want us to work on is Exits and Entrys (Entrys if needed).

A more generic, programmable exit:  
  
Close trade when the 14,3,3 stoch. of 1/8th the time period of the long time period to enter the trade gives an opposite signal.  
  
So if 60/240 is used to enter 1/8 of 240 is 30min (14,3,3) is used to exit.

So everyone want's a signal generated and NOT a trade opened. Right?  
  
I only had one exit idea posted ([http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost...postcount=1878](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=1497659&postcount=1878) )  
  
What I'll do is put in the ability to choose your exit timeframe. But the stoch for the exit time frame (exittimeframe in the EA) will be 14,3,3.  
  
New variables:  
**audioAlert** = false; if true it plays annoying sound and flip open dialog box  
**emailAlert** = false; if true it will send an e-mail alert to the e-mail address that's in Metatrader 4 options area.  
**submitautoorder** = false; if true, will submit order for you  
**closeautoorder** = false; if true, will auto close order for you.  
**exittimeframe** = 240; time frame for closeautoorder.  
  
ALL ARE SET TO FALSE BY DEFAULT! In other words, it will not do anything until you set something to true.  
  
Test and play.  
  
Ps. you guys doing back testing (hopefully a full calendar year like 2006) post some results (you get them from the report tab in the strategy tester area in MT4). Of course, if your back testing w/ all the automatic stuff turned on.  
  
Hey TEB, chime in any time buddy!![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)   
  
Thanks!

Kills the whole thing. It'll work for Dustin when he's doing news due to the volitility of it, but not when your trading trends.   
  
IF you were to use this trading trends, you should use it on a daily chart. That way settings won't be reset on a new candle.

TEB3 SIMPLE  
  
1\. Remove everything from your charts ....I mean everything!!  
2\. Add two sma 4 closed (Blue) sma 5 open (red)  
(if you don't have open & closed then 3 &7 SMA works also)   
3\. move to the weekly chart get trend (blue & red lines )  
4\. move to the daily charts to get triggers ( pink arrows)  
5\. move to the 4 hour to get comformation ( black arrows)  
3rd charts   
  
week charts- you see trend blue & red lines only go with them   
day charts - are triggers ( pink arrows) & stops (Pink "X")  
4 hour - conformations of buy/sell (black arrows)  
you want all 3 going the same ways  
  
you are in and out on the day charts.  
when the weekly turns you are out big time   
you can take 1/2 when the 4 hour turns   
or add to your trade when the 4 hour goes the way you want   
SL atlease 50pips   
TP let it ride.  
you will have small loses - & big wins   
  
its that simple.

> TEB3 SIMPLE  
>    
>  1\. Remove everything from your charts ....I mean everything!!  
>  2\. Add two sma 4 closed (Blue) sma 5 open (red)  
>  (if you don't have open & closed then 3 &7 SMA works also)   
>  3\. move to the weekly chart get trend (blue & red lines )  
>  4\. move to the daily charts to get triggers ( pink arrows)  
>  5\. move to the 4 hour to get comformation ( black arrows)  
>  3rd charts   
>    
>  week charts- you see trend blue & red lines only go with them   
>  day charts - are triggers ( pink arrows) & stops (Pink "X")  
>  4 hour - conformations of buy/sell (black arrows)  
>  you want all 3 going the same ways  
>    
>  you are in and out on the day charts.  
>  when the weekly turns you are out big time   
>  you can take 1/2 when the 4 hour turns   
>  or add to your trade when the 4 hour goes the way you want   
>  SL atlease 50pips   
>  TP let it ride.  
>  you will have small loses - & big wins   
>    
>  its that simple.

TEB,  
  
I am most greatful for everything you have shared. It has taken 5 days to read every post to this point. I might have been faster had I not been playing with each of the systems you have presented here. A sincere thanks to everyone else participating here as well.  
  
It is very interesting that I have stumbled upon quite a few pips in the last few days. I'm starting to look like some kind of genius trader ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f923.png?v=15.1) . But of course my genius is only my ability to synthesize what is put before me. I certainly haven't created anything to date. However, I am having some fun looking at a merge of some of your systems with some old tools I have developed or been working with. Rest assured if I find something with some strong correlation I will not hesitate to share it with the rest of you.  
  
Thanks again. And a special thanks to you coders out there who are swinging away at this. I beleive TEB is not keen on the automation, and I certainly understand. But until I have more money and time to sit at the screen and run this more like a full time business, I'm looking for every advantage I can to find entries and apply exit strategy updates when I'm away at my day job. I am learning to code myself and everything you folks present is real grist for my mill.  
  
To that end, let me suggest that a complete EA is not always what we might be looking for. Some code that allows you to say, identify a trendline already placed on your chart with an offset, for a stop loss. Or maybe an EA that can recognize two lines as a channel for a stop loss and TP for an existing position... Of course we'd have to put a trade on with a magic number or provide an active (open) order number to make it work... and some object identifiers for the lines. At least that way you could manage a position with an EA while you had to be away. If you come back, and the position is still open you just turn off the EA and manage it on your own. Working in this way would lead you toward automating a full EA that recognizes channels you personally draw. Then all you have to do is add a component that recognizes the channels -- that's the easy part, right? ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f923.png?v=15.1) . But really, building a tool that applies rules for SL and TP on an existing position using channels we identify to it would allow me to keep a position open with a known self adjusting risk:reward while I'm away at work. I think most people would prefer that to closing a winning position or placing a stop loss, and it would allow you programmers to progress toward something more fully automated anyway.  
  
That's much more than I intended to post. Sorry to those it bothers... I know you are out there. But I really appreciate what everyone has contributed. Thanks so very much. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)   
  
Qman

  * [#2,061](/thread/post/1523220#post1523220 "Post Permalink")

  * Aug 4, 2007 2:56am  Aug 4, 2007 2:56am 

  * [ Rocroy](rocroy)

  * | Joined Jun 2007  | Status: Trader | [643 Posts](/search?do=process&provider=Member&searchuser=41496)

The channel format is a part of a template that was originally developed for Orange Roshnan's SRDCII system (check the thread, lots of good stuff there). Much of the method is about channels and price movements in the channels.   
  
The channel I've used is a Fib channel, and when the template is activated, the additional lines are automatically drawn in the channel.  
  
You can use additional lines (or the four quartals) for openings. FOr instance, don't open a buy position if the price in topmost quartal during uptrend, even if other indicators like stochs would propose that. Or, whenever the lowest quartal is entered during uptrend, open a buy position.  
  
Lines can also be used for exits, e.g. close half of your position when the middle line is crossed, and let the rest run.  
  
The SRDCII method description contains a collection of rules that can be applied with the template.   
  
R

Papertraded TEB3 on euro. Trading was started on 02/09/2007 when the weekly trend turned up and continued up till now. Used W/D/4hr TFs.  
  
The potential of trading on daily chart was 1649 pips, of which TEB3 was able to capture 514 pips, about 30% of the potential. Montly average is about 85 pips.  
  
The main problem of the system is that it reacts slowly to trend changes. If you only look at the MA lines and crosses, everything looks good, but in real life price may be far far away from the MA like in the example exit.  
  
R

The message probably came out a bit too harsh. We need to keep in mind that TEB3 is a winning system, which requires only a small amount of effort to be run. Unlike many other systems presented in this forum, it is also explicit, and the results are repeatable. Applied to four main pairs, it is likely to give some 300-400 pips per month. Not bad at all...  
  
I'm personally more fond of TEB2. When it is combined with channels (which can overcome TEB2 difficulties during strong, longlasting trends) the results can be really good. Channels (or trendlines), when properly used, is imo the only indicator that is capable of really forecasting future price development. All the others are more or less documenting what has happened, ie what the price did.  
  
The problem with channels is that they are subjective, and difficult to determine when trend is chaning. I'm still developing TEB2-channel rule set for my purposes.  
  
R

Flame  
I also seriously consider exiting on the 4hr. Sometimes I would have had more pips getting out at a 1 hr crossover, other times at the 4 hr. Right now it's about/50/50 and the jury is still out.   
  
There's of course more exits & re-entries with the 1 hr, but pips in the pocket is what it's all about. Probably it just boils down to what psychologically is comfortable for you.  
  
The bottom line is once you have a winning strategy (which all of the TEB strategies are) with a good percentage of positive trades I have reached the conclusion that the # of pips gained on one over the other may be irrelevant! Splitting hairs can drive you crazy! I can tell you that I originally started trading with 1 lot - and now I enter with 3 lots per trade. My account is growing better now than it has done in the past 3 years!  
  
'Trading Naked' (no indicators - other than EMA's) wound up to be the smartest move I ever made! With TEB's systems fear and greed no longer rear their ugly heads and determine when I pull the trigger and when I exit. Actually, the forex has become fun, something I have'nt experienced in a long time!

Maybe u didnt now study candlesticks properly or your mentor did not show you how to recognize candlestick formations.   
  
If you look at gbp/usd 4hr chart on monday 6 aug around 12:00 then you will see a nice little hammer followed by a bullish engulfment. that trade would have given you close to 244 pips depending on where u entered.   
  
Eur/jpy. had the exact same formation that would have given u around 161 pips depending where u entered.   
  
Usd/jpy gave you the 3 white soldiers formation...offering 116 pips.   
  
Nzd/jpy had the exact same formation offering you 167 pips.   
  
Aud/jpy had the same formation offering 115 pips.   
  
Usd/cad and Eur/cad and eur/aud had nice bearish engulfments offering between 50 and 100 pips each   
  
Eur/chf has a bullish engulfment offering 50plus pips  
  
Yesterday was a very easy trading day in which you could have made LOTS of pips by just following basic candlestick formations as presented on the 4hr charts.  
  
If i may be so blunt....see if you can find someone trading candlesticks successfully...and sit next to him while he is trading....a whole NEW WORLD will open up to you  
  
anyway candlesticks are not the topic of this thread....i wish u all good trading

I use 4H and 30m. Also sometimes I see at the daily but my main tool is the 4H and the trigger is the 30m.   
  
It is exactly as TEB said. There are times when you can cheat a bit (i.e. when not both stochs cross on the 30m) and still make money but if someone follows the rules it is good as it gets ( I said that yesterday but i truly believe it and I trade the FX for a bit over 2 years now).   
  
In addition, spend some time (5-10 mins) before you start trading and try to spot the 4H channels. Every day there will be definetely 2-3 pairs that form decent 4H channels (by decent I mean at least 2 tops and 2 bottoms). When you find them, use them. It is almost a crime for somebody not to use the 4H channels when spotted.

I looked at TEB 1 when it was posted but didn't progress with it. I recently came across TEB 3 and a quick inspection has sparked an huge interest in its possibilities.  
  
Can someone familiar/experienced (TEB63 ?) with this method confirm a few details please?  
  
The chart indicators are simply: a SMA 4 Close (blue) and a SMA 5 Open(red).  
  
CHart 1 (weekly)  
An MA cross here gives the trend direction.  
Q Does this trend remain valid ('hold') until the opposite cross?  
Q When the MA slopes deteriorate does this also indicate the end of the trend?  
  
CH2 (daily)  
This chart is where trading is done. A cross of the MAs in the same direction as the trend on CH1 indicates a possible entry (pink arrow).   
Q Exit is indicated by a reverse cross? (pink 'X')  
  
CH3 (4 hour)  
Is used for confirmation. An MA cross here in the same direction confirms the entry seen on CH2.   
Q Should the confirmation cross occur AFTER the entry cross on CH2 or does it not matter?  
Additions and 50% TPs are possible at new H4 crosses or turns -Q as long as the CH2 trend continues?  
  
My initial tests on various charts shows big possibilities for TEB 3. Most of the pairs I've looked at seem to work very well but does anyone have any recommendations which pairs to use?

use it as a filter.  
  
Ie on my charts

down with a black candle   
red candle can tell you a change is coming

Guys, how do you actually use channels?  
  
Here is one way I use channel info. The channel here is pointing up, and it sometimes happens that stochs on 4H chart do not show when the trend (here downtrend - the thick red line) changes. For instance in this example you could not draw the last thick green line using 4H stochs, they both stay well above 20, and you would miss the next upmove.  
  
So, I check the 1H chart and if both stochs on that chart visit under 20 like here, I take that as a signal that the trend is up, and start opening buy positions based on 30M chart. Especially, if the price is near channel borders. In this way I ease up the TEB2 rules a little, depending on the channel direction.  
  
Note that this 1H stoch lows near the earlier down channel upper boundary also indicates the end for this channel.  
  
R

Personally i trade the TEB2

It is even stronger if all of the crosses happen approximately the same time (4H and 30m).   
  
However I still trade (observing 4H channels and candles) if the crosses do not take place in the overbought/sold territories and it is still profitable.

Hi there,   
  
TEB might have additional comments to this, but imo the idea is to identify the long term trend using a slower timeframe (like a 4H chart where you insert a thick green or red line as the trend on that TF changes), and then move to faster TF (1H) and pick up there the spots where the trend changes to the direction of the slower TF. In this way we make sure that we are trading with the trend, not against it, trying to minimize risk and maximising the profit.  
  
So, if on 4H TF the trend is down, you place sell positions, when the stochs on 1H have been over 80 and fall again below that limit. If you get in too early, like in the example you show, there is a high risk that the price still continues to move against you, as stochs have not reached the desired (overbought) value.  
  
R

My experience is that stoch systems, especially TEB2, perform much better than MAs.  
  
The problem I had when using TEB2 was that the slower stoch did not always show the trend correctly. During long steady trends the slower (e.g. 4H) stoch would indicate that trend is changing, but in many cases that was not true. So, instead of using stochs for determining the big trend, I moved to trendlines, like the graph shows.   
  
I draw a trendline on the slower TF (e.g. 4H) and then move to a faster TF (1H) where I use stochs for entries.  
  
But like you say, MA's can also be used for trend determination.  
  
R

TEB2:  
  
Stochs; 5.3.3 aand 14.3.3  
  
charts: 4h and 30m.   
  
Look for crosses on the 4h and draw a line when they occur. then move to 30m and when they cross enter. Stronger signal when they happen simultaneously (or as close as possible).   
  
If you obey the rules it is difficult to lose. yesterday 21/09 I went long GBPJPY at approx 06:00 am GMT. 3 of the 4 crosses were in place and I said what the hell, the 4th is about to come. It did come finally half an hour later after I had been stopped for 35 pips. Had I waited for the 4th cross it would have netted me zillions of pips. So the moral of the story is that patience is a virtue.   
  
Also the system is great if you can manage to follow the rules. Of course you can bent the rules a little if you feel it is going to happen. Yesterday it didnt happen for me but it does happen more often than not. I mean if I have the 3 out of 4 crosses in place i usually enter and end in profit.  
  
Hope it helps.   
  
Oh, I also use 4H channels, they are great and easy to find

TEB   
  
I've been trying this (is this maybe TEB4?) method for the last week or so with excellent results.   
Some slight timing changes though: to detect trends more quickly I'm doing H8 instead of daily for the trend -- but still using H4 for trading.  
  
I actually look at the Daily first to see the broader trend but the H8 is the decider. I fine tune entry on the H4 by checking the H1.  
  
So in summary: D1 then _H8 for trend_ , _H4 for trading_ having glanced at the H1 to verify the correct candle colour.   
All with MAs only, I don't like Stochastics.  
  
I'll be running this again next week so maybe more to report then.

> Hi there,   
>    
>  TEB might have additional comments to this, but imo the idea is to identify the long term trend using a slower timeframe (like a 4H chart where you insert a thick green or red line as the trend on that TF changes), and then move to faster TF (1H) and pick up there the spots where the trend changes to the direction of the slower TF. In this way we make sure that we are trading with the trend, not against it, trying to minimize risk and maximising the profit.  
>    
>  So, if on 4H TF the trend is down, you place sell positions, when the stochs on 1H have been over 80 and fall again below that limit. If you get in too early, like in the example you show, there is a high risk that the price still continues to move against you, as stochs have not reached the desired (overbought) value.

hey guess, it seems that you are pulling the trigger too soon. when the stochs cross on the 4hr, you should wait for the 30m to cross from the same relative position whether it be around or slightly above/below 20 or 80. for example, on your chart, you have the 4hr cross from around the 50. think TEB likes crosses below 50 and not to mention if they can be around the 20 even better. therefore, on the 30min chart, you need to be looking for the crosses at least below the 50 line of the stochs. the stronger moves tend to be closer to the the 20 line (and the 80 line in a downtrend). you can take those crosses that you have shown in your chart but those are low probability trades. you want to take the high probability trades.  
  
i hope this helps. see if you can find the teb2 section and read up on it. its a lot i know to sift through, but it can be worth your while.

A couple of charts on euro. You notice that on 4H chart euro has broken the trendline, which means that now the 4H trend is down. If you try to use here 4H stochs they give a false indication that the trend would be up again after a short down period and you would be looking for longs instead of shorts... That is why i ended up using trendlines insteads of stoch for 4H trend.  
  
So you go to 30M chart and identify stoch tops for shorting, and you notice that you could enter in three places. At least here that 30 pips SL would have been enough, but you could even go to 5M chart and look for an optimal entry point.  
  
And when this new downtrend is forming up, you can draw a trendline when the first two tops are there and use the trendline for entries (when the price touches the line and stochs confirm that it is ok to enter). Remember to update the trendline whenever new tops (like in this downtrend) are formed.  
  
R

Hey muyuam, the only advice I can give you is:  
  
1\. find out what time frames work for you. if you can sit at the computer all day, then maybe watching the 4hr, 30 system is good for you. if you cant, then try it out on different higher timeframes.  
  
2\. take only the best trades. wait for the stochs to line up at the correct levels and take those trades. be careful though, no system is 100% and sometimes you will suffer losses. just keep practicing until you have it down right and then practice some more to ensure you know it inside out. I am still testing my strategy but also testing others so I have not devoted the entire time to testing TEB2.  
  
3\. protect yourself always. use a stop loss!!  
  
thats all for now, I am not that good in this system as yet, still practicing.

generally in an uptrend, you want the 30m to cross BELOW the 50 line and close to the 20 line if possible. You can take that trade as the cross is near the 50, however that is not a prime trade. if you were going to take that trade, possibly try with a smaller amount than you usually trade with.  
  
with regards for exit and S/L those a difficult questions. you kinda have to figure out how much you are willing to risk and how much you want to profit. I personally use position sizing to properly calculate my risk and I like to put stops a little bit past areas of support and resistance. when the market moves in my direction, I am testing taking some profit and move the stop to breakeven so that I don't lose money. hope this helps.

hey guys, i found an indicator that could make teb style trading much easier. it is called 4tf stoch bars. this indicator is really nice. what it does is place the stoch readings from 4 time frames and display them as green and red (default) up or down and thus makes it visually easier for you to see what is going on in several time frames by just viewing one time frame.  
  
apparently what it does is take 4 successive time frames to display on the chart starting with the one that you put it on and then it goes up according to default mt4 tf settings. for example, if you put this indicator on the 15m, it will display 15m, 30m, 1h, 4h. if you place it on the 4h it will display 4h, D,W,M. so far as i know it is not customizable without some tweaking for custom time frames.  
  
there are a few nuances with this indicator and I wanted to know if there is anyone who can help me improve this indicator. the biggest problem with this indicator is its repainting. lets say for example you place the indicator on the 1h and you have displayed 1h, 4h, d, w. lets say the 1h stoch is down and the 4h stoch is up. when the 4h stoch starts to turn down, it apparently will repaint the entire 4 hr bar represented in dots at times. for example, at some point the 4h is displaying green (up) when it switches about 4 dots will switch red. this can lead to false signals and can hurt traders. what i think should be done to improve the indicator is that whatever is the smallest tf displayed, all other boxes should be marked off at that regular time interval whether it be up or down. that way you won't have the higher time frames changing multiple dots, it will only change the most recent/current dot.  
  
here is the indicator:  
[http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost...2&postcount=24](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=1631092&postcount=24)  
  
i have tried PM'ing banzai and i am waiting on a reply but i think that if we can tweak this thing...it will be very helpful to a lot of traders.  
  
what you guys think?  
  
take care and happy trading.

Good to see the thread is still going. I'm still using TEB2, but I have 4 windows per each pair: 30min, 4hr, daily, and weekly. The reason for the 4 timeframes is that I can use combinations of different pairs for the same currency: 30min/4hr (the standard TEB2), 4hr/daily, daily/weekly. Also, sometimes I switch weekly with 5min to see the exact entry on 30min/4hr. The best trades of course happen when daily, 4hr, and 30min lign up (from TEB1), and by best trades I mean the amounts of pips, they are large when that happens. Once I had all of them ligned up, including weekly, on EUR/JPY, grabbed 120 pips and chickened out, but the pair kept falling for another 300 or so pips.   
  
For the supp/res i use TL's, fibs, previous swing highs/lows; and also candlestick formations for reverse/retrace confirmation. I've given up on channels because I find previous swing high/low levels to give me more accurate results. And of course the stochs, when they lign up, we get the momentum.  
  
Great system, thnx Teb.

**_3 ducks system_**  
<http://captaincurrency.blogspot.com/>  
  
  
Firstly I would like to say, I did not reinvent the wheel with this system, I have just added one or two ideas to a 60 period simple moving average (sma) to make it my own and named it "The 3 Duck's Trading System" for obvious reasons as you will find out later on. The system is fairly straight forward and easy to use. Like a lot of trading systems it will be more productive when prices are moving in one direction and not stuck in a tight trading range. Of course this system has losing trade and losing runs, but with proper money management and good discipline I'm sure this system will keep you out of bad trades and give you a great chance to make profits in the Fx market. One of the nice things about this system is it will quickly tell you if prices are in an up or down swing phase and stop you from guessing! It will also allow you to decide to be a bull or a bear and trade in the direction of that trend. There are 3 charts involved in this system: a 4hr chart, a 1hr chart and a 5min chart. There is 1 indicator, a 60 period simple moving average (60 sma) plotted on each chart. There you go, its that simple.  
  
**How it works:**  
  
  
Step 1 - **First Duck**  
**[](http://bp0.blogger.com/_o93gCdxWKlc/Ru7DoZl7SBI/AAAAAAAAAX8/51Kqfr7CJLs/s1600-h/4hr+cable.bmp)[http://bp0.blogger.com/_o93gCdxWKlc/.../4hr+cable.bmp](http://bp0.blogger.com/_o93gCdxWKlc/Ru7DoZl7SBI/AAAAAAAAAX8/51Kqfr7CJLs/s200/4hr+cable.bmp)**  
The first thing we need to do is look at our largest time-frame (4hr chart) and see if **current prices** are **above** or **below** the 60 sma. From this chart we can see that current price is **below** the 60 sma. This tells us that we maybe looking to sell.  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
Step 2-**Second Duck**  
[](http://bp3.blogger.com/_o93gCdxWKlc/Ru7FSJl7SDI/AAAAAAAAAYM/jO7JK8k2osU/s1600-h/cable+1hr.bmp)[http://bp3.blogger.com/_o93gCdxWKlc/.../cable+1hr.bmp](http://bp3.blogger.com/_o93gCdxWKlc/Ru7FSJl7SDI/AAAAAAAAAYM/jO7JK8k2osU/s200/cable+1hr.bmp)The second thing we need to do is drop down to our 1hr chart. We need to see the current price below the 60 sma on this chart also, this gives us **confirmation**.  
Important: If the current price was to be above the 60 sma on this chart we could not move on to step 3.  
  
  
  
Step 3 - **Third Duck**  
[](http://bp1.blogger.com/_o93gCdxWKlc/Ru-7VZl7SJI/AAAAAAAAAY8/bYVcTHSsNDs/s1600-h/5min+cable.bmp)[http://bp1.blogger.com/_o93gCdxWKlc/...5min+cable.bmp](http://bp1.blogger.com/_o93gCdxWKlc/Ru-7VZl7SJI/AAAAAAAAAY8/bYVcTHSsNDs/s200/5min+cable.bmp)From step 1 and 2, current prices need to be below their 60 sma's on each chart. We are now on the 5 min chart and we are looking to sell when price crosses below the 60 sma. For extra confirmation we should let prices break the last low on the 5 min chart. This would mean that prices will be below their 60 sma on all 3 time-frames, therefore all 3 Ducks are lined up in the same direction.  
  
  
**Stop-Losses:** This is where you can make this system your own. If you are a short term trader you may want to put your stop-loss above the highs on the 5 min or the 1 hr chart. If you are more of a positional trader you may wish to put your stop-loss above a high on the 4 hr chart. You could also use a fixed stop-loss, maybe 25-30 pips or more from entry. It all depends what type of a trader you are, so you decide! If you are a longer term trader or investor, this system can help you get a good entry point into the market. Another "trick" that may help you preserve capital, If you do sell and prices get back above the 5 min 60 sma by 10 pips (not a good sign) you may want to cut your losses short before your stop-loss. But if you are a longer term trader this may not be a big deal for you.  
  
  
**Targets:** Same again, depends what type of a trader you are but target can be support or resistance levels.  
  
  
**Summary:** The above example was carried out when the gbp/usd was trading lower so obviously we where selling - the system works just as well for buying opportunities, just look for prices to be **above** the 60 sma on all 3 time-frames, starting with step 1 again. I like this system a lot as it does not try to out-guess the markets movements and pick tops and bottoms. The system will quickly tell you to be a buyer or a seller. Its a good honest system that tries to follow prices. This system works better on currency pairs such as the Eur/Usd and Gbp/Usd, but there is nothing stopping you from plotting this system on any pair, but as we know some pairs act differently to others. The best time I found for trading this system is the European and US sessions. I lke to use this system as a guide in addition to my own market knowledge. Take care to watch what is going on around you - economic new releases, holidays etc.  
  
by Captain Currency

I'm using TEB on the lower timeframes 5m,15m,1H with an eye on the 4H and D1.  
  
I have noticed that the oversold (below 20) and overbought (over 80) levels can serve as a marker to support/resistance. And keeping an eye on divergence on the 15m is helping with the confidence of the 5m signals.  
  
After hitting support and coverging and getting 3 blue signals lining up... I went long at .9950 and took profit at the 80 handle... sure enough overboght signals showed up.  
  
I've averaged 6% a day on my real money account this week in a "trade as I study" this system. So far, I haven't had a losing day yet with very low drawdowns.

I became familiar with the TEB system about a year ago, but never really got it going for me. But recently, I started fooling around with it as a longer term trade, using the weekly and daily charts. I guess it's more of a TEB 2 system. Anyway I have had very promising results backtesting several pairs from the first of this year till now.   
  
The way I tested was like this. I determined the direction of the weekly and only took daily signals in that direction. On each signal that was generated, I took a one lot trade on the next candle that broke the high or low of the signal candle. I set a fixed stop at around 80 to 100% of the pair's Daily ATR depending on the pair, and set the limit at twice the stop. There were no add ons, no trailing stops, and no scaling out or taking early profits. Six pairs were tested. There were 64 trades, with 36 winners for a 56.3% winning percentage. The total profit was 6,025 pips. There was a fairly hefty 1,725 pip drawdown, the result of a stretch of ten losers in a row.   
  
I think this is pretty exciting for a set it and forget it approach. Something to think about is that I used almost no discretion in these test trades. If it was a signal, I took it, no matter where the stoch cross occurred. A little discretion and some more logical stop and limit placement might produce a better winning percentage and a better return per trade, which by the way was about 94 pips average.   
  
Is anybody else trading this method like this? I'd like to hear from and exchange ideas with those who might be, or even might be interested.  
  
  
Cheers,  
Richard

Red,  
  
Hi. You're right about multiple time frames, but the basis is the use of stochastics as opposed to moving averages. You set up two different time charts each with two stochastic oscillators on them, and when the stochs are in agreement, that is all crossed in the same direction, you enter the trade. This a variation of the method first described at the beginning of this thread, but TEB 2 is formulated and discussed here as well. There are certain subleties to reading stochastics that are also discussed throughout this thread that you will find helpful. There is also a short thread on TEB 2 which gives the specifics--- <http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=61902>  
  
Initially TEB 2 was designed to be a day trading strategy, but it seems to adapt well to a swing/position application. Take a look and see what you think.  
  
  
Cheers,  
Richard

In Metatrader 4 if you _right click_ on the toolbar (say where the arrow or vertical bar icons are located) a menu will open. If you click on "customize" it will enable you to add the regression channel icon to your toolbar. This saves having to click on the INSERT|CHANNELS menu items.  
  
The regression channel icon (it's labelled on the customize menu) is the single slash line with the hash marks across it.

Hi Teb, good stuff, I've been using slow stochastics 14, 6 as my main indicator on about 6 timeframes. It spots trend peaks and valleys quicker than the MACD, but there is an art to it.  
  
I use 4m, 20m, 1hr, 4hr, 1day, 1week, and I judge the trend by looking at the slow stochastics of each timeframe. It is safest when at least the 4 and 20 minute stochastics line up, but the more that are in sync the bigger the move that will occur in time so that one may let one's position ride if one chooses.  
  
I use thinkorswim and just have like 6 chart snippets. I would suggest looking at the stochastics of all 6 to learn the process. It is an art because there is often a price peak or valley within overbought or oversold stochastics period which is the optimal entry point (rather than when it crosses above 20 or below 80).  
  
I use real tight stops, .05%, which is like 5 pips. If I get stopped out I try to enter again real soon at a better entry, because it is even more overbought or oversold at this time. My exit is when the stochastics move to whatever extreme unless I feel the move is faltering and will come back on me, then I just exit at that time.  
  
Right now I am using MACD, and ADX/DMI too, but am trying to streamline the complexity of my system down (which is still simple). I'll post my system and graphics once I get it stabilized. I am a relatively new trader and I find multiple timeframe trading using slow stochastics, MACD, or similar, to be the key to profitability. One can trade anything with this system too.

If you look at your chart, you'll see that MTF Stoch for D1 has crossed down on 13/4 at 00:00 whereas if you put a normal 533 stoch on D1 separately, you'll see that stoch crossed when daily bar closed. MTF shows daily stoch cross down when daily bar still open.  
  
If the daily trend continues up or down, this is not a problem as you follow H4 and M30. But when Daily stoch crosses up or down, MTF indi always shows stoch cross when the daily bar is still open.   
  
Of course, this is the case with H4 and M30 stoch crossing moments when using MTF stoch indi as stoch crosses happen when the bar is still open.  
  
TEB explained how to tackle this as having experience with the indi and get a feeling for it when someone asked the same question.  
  
I wonder how you are handling this. When you open a position in D1 direction while the bar is still open and all of a sudden price reverses and D1 stoch reverses and crosses back , what do you do or what are you planning to do if you haven't seen such a case yet?
